awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Low Cost Copper Contacts with Built in Barriers for Crystalline Silicon Solar Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project aims to develop copper based pastes for the metallization of silicon solar cells. Photovoltaics (PV) offer an opportunity for clean and affordable energy and over the past decade the PV industry has seen annual compound growth rates of over 50%. Although revenues are high, the profit margins for many manufacturers have substantially diminished, necessitating the need for cutbacks throughout the value chain. One area marked for cost reduction, is in the metallization of the solar cells, which now commands nearly 10 percent of the world's supply. Having the cost of photovoltaic panels tied to a precious metal with price volatility can lead to higher prices for renewable energy; thus replacing silver with copper is a significant opportunity for the industry. Thus the outcomes of this project would be a product for making solar energy more affordable. The project also includes creating two new full time positions in Kentucky in Advanced Research and Manufacturing. This proposal will enhance scientific understanding of the copper-silicon contact formation and durability of the material during operation. 

The technological feasibility of the copper pastes with an inherent diffusion barrier was demonstrated on standard and bifacial solar cells in Phase I. Phase II will further improve the screen printable pastes to industry standards. To achieve the high electrical performance required in this market, the project will investigate the copper-silicon interface to investigate the mechanisms involved during contact formation, and the chemical nature of the copper-silicon interface. This information will be used to optimize the chemical composition and thermal treatment of the pastes to improve electrical performance and cell lifetime. The pastes will be optimized for industrial operating equipment to provide the manufacturer with a product that can be dropped in, with minimal changes to the production line. Phase II will also involve scale up of the core materials in the pastes to be able to engage customers in further printing trials. Through the assembly and testing of prototype solar cell modules, the durability of the copper contacts will be demonstrated. The outcomes of this proposal will be screen printable copper pastes that can be direct drop in replacement for the silver pastes; thereby enhancing the profit margins of the solar cell manufacturer.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The photovoltaics (PV) industry continues to grow rapidly with the International Technology Roadmap for PV (ITRPV) reporting cell and module capacity increasing to 300 GWp at the end of 2020. Crystalline silicon (c-Si) cells dominate the market with a 95% share, and since the 1970's have continued to use screen printable silver (Ag) pastes for the front electrical contacts. Significant price fluctuations have led to Ag thrifting within the industry and attempts to replace Ag with copper (Cu) have utilized routes employed by the micro-electronics industry. Unlike Ag, the physical and chemical properties mean Cu is more susceptible to oxidation, as well as enabling it to diffuse more easily into Si; damaging the device's efficiency if no additional barrier layers are used. This has required the anti-reflective coating (ARC) first be opened, before a separate diffusion barrier is deposited. The cell is then annealed before the Cu contact is electroplated on top. A capping layer of tin or Ag finishes the contact, to prevent oxidation. These additional processing steps add more material and CapEx costs. Other approaches using Cu based pastes have also required the use of Ag in the formulation or have needed separate diffusion barriers and/or processing under a reducing atmosphere. Thus, like the Cu electroplating process, these additional steps cut into the cost savings made when switching from Ag to Cu.

BERT THIN FILMS LLC (BTF) is a Kentucky based company developing Cu based metallization pastes; CuBertTM for c-Si solar cells. The company was originally formed to commercialize Cu based inks developed in the Conn Center for Renewable Energy Research at the University of Louisville. Unlike other approaches, CuBertTM was developed to be a direct drop-in replacement. Similarly, to the incumbent technology, the paste can (1) be fired in air, (2) etch through the anti-reflective coating and (3) has been shown to have an inherent diffusion barrier allowing the paste to be printed directly on the c-Si solar cell.

The NSF SBIR phase II/IIB award was used to develop (1) CuBertTM, a high temperature screen printable paste for standard c-Si solar cells, and (2) CuBert.BFTM, a low temperature paste for bifacial Si cells which cannot exceed 250 degrees celsius during processing. At the end of the 18-month reporting period the decision was made to halt work on CuBert.BFTM, in order to concentrate efforts on CuBertTM, the high temperature paste, due to market demand. This award was used optimize the materials and formulation; thereby improving the printability of the paste and electrical performance of the fired contacts. The paste was tested on both small (~4x4 cm2) and full sized (~15.9x15.9 cm2) cells. The improvements led to the width of the contacts (fingers) being reduced to less than 100 microns and printing of continuous lines on full sized cells. Development of CuBertTM was originally on both poly and mono c-Si cells with a full aluminum back surface field (Al-BSF) type structure. The open circuit voltage (Voc) and pseudo fill factor (pFF) are expected to decrease over time if Cu diffuses into the junction. By thermally stressing the cells at elevated temperatures and monitoring the performance of these parameters, the quality of the inherent diffusion barrier can be established. CuBertTM metallized poly c-Si cells maintained stable pFF and Voc over extended periods at elevated temperatures. As the project progressed, the cell structure transitioned to mono c-Si passivated emitter and rear contact (PERC) solar cells with a selective emitter. In recent years, these high efficiency devices have gained traction, with passivated contact type cells accounting for over 60% of the PV market. Full sized cells were fired in air using a six-zone industrial IR belt furnace with the highest efficiency of 19.28% being measured for a cell. Further accelerated aging tests, incorporating the cells into miniature modules, and exposing them to elevated temperatures and humidity was also carried out.  These tests showed that the initial minority carrier lifetime, is a predicter of the quality of the diffusion barrier, and the lifespan of the cells under these test conditions. The results obtained under this award were used to shore up the intellectual property for the CuBertTM technology, with a full PCT patent application filed at the end of 2020.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/23/2021
Modified by: Ruvini Dharmadasa
